Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF CREST Bioenergy Center at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T)

The Bioenergy Center at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) will be an educational and research resource for the United States in the field of thermochemical conversion of biomass to bioenergy. The efficient and economic production of energy from biomass and other renewable natural resources is necessary to transform the U.S. energy industry to energy independence and sustainability. Thermochemical catalytic conversion of biomass to liquid fuels and hydrogen is widely recognized as a technology critical to achieving these goals.

The major focuses of the Bioenergy Center will be on developing advanced thermochemical biomass conversion technologies for the production of liquid transportation fuels and hydrogen and educating the engineers and scientists who will be needed to propel the biofuels industry forward into the 21st century. The overarching goals are to:

1) through research, education and outreach, spur development and commercialization of advanced thermochemical biomass conversion technologies for the efficient and economic production of liquid transportation fuels, hydrogen and chemicals;

2) provide education and training in the field of bioenergy for underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students, and career development for underrepresented scientists in the field of bioenergy;

3) serve as a pipeline for students from kindergarten up through graduate level into bioenergy related STEM disciplines and careers; and

4) create an interdisciplinary community of learning, discovery, and engagement at NCA&T that will promote excellence and internal and external collaboration in the bioenergy area.

To provide a national resource for improving the efficiencies and economics of thermochemical biomass conversion technology, the Bioenergy Center's research is focused in three thrust areas:

(I) Production of high-quality synthesis gas (a mixture containing varying amounts of carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2) by biomass gasification,
(II) Conversion of synthesis gas to liquid fuels and hydrogen, and
(III) Reforming and processing of biofuels for fuel cells.

Innovative aspects of the research projects include development of:
(1) thermochemical processes that have minimal carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions with high energy efficiency;
(2) microreactors for catalyst screening and higher yields of liquid fuels from synthesis gas;
(3) novel multi-metallic catalysts that produce H2 with minimal CO formation;
(4) membrane-reactor systems that produce high-purity H2 from reforming reactions;
(5) Proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) electrodes that have CO-tolerant, high-surface area, low platinum (Pt)-loading electrocatalysts; and
(6) economic analysis of technology choices that will be explicitly concentrated on biomass and energy prices as well as bioenergy policy provisions.

Additionally, there will be a focus on using evaluation data to contribute to the scholarly literature on best practices for the recruitment, retention, and professional development of underrepresented students and faculty members.

The Bioenergy Center will involve 10 faculty members from 6 academic departments (Biological Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, Mathematics, Economics and Energy & Environmental Systems) and 1 faculty member at Louisiana Tech (Chemical Engineering). A seed grant program will bring in additional faculty from among minority groups who have been heretofore underrepresented in the STEM disciplines. Funding will be used to equip 4 bioenergy research labs, further develop two existing interdisciplinary Ph.D. programs, and support underrepresented minority students and faculty members. The research, education and industry partnerships emerging from the Bioenergy Center are expected to move North Carolina and the Southeast closer to leadership in the bioenergy industry.

Research, education and outreach will be achieved through a wide and diverse family of partners, including Louisiana Tech, the new Guilford County Schools system's STEM Early College on the NCA&T campus, the N.C. Community College biofuels initiative, the Biofuels Center of North Carolina, the Kenan Fellows Program for Curriculum and Leadership Development, the Natural Science Center of Greensboro, federal labs and several bioenergy companies. Educational materials about the center's research will be disseminated to partners. Effort will be expended to include other HBCU and minority serving institutions in online seminars and courses, as well as an international bioenergy conference, to insure broad, equitable access to the myriad economic and educational opportunities that bioenergy promises.

Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

ProgramElement.Text: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

POR.DRECONTENT:
After five years of operation, The CREST Center for Bioenergy at NC A&T State University (NC A&T) has become an educational and research resource for the Nation in the field of thermochemical conversion of biomass to bioenergy. Its objectives are to: 1) conduct fundamental research towards the development of advanced thermochemical biomass conversion technology and intellectual property for the efficient and economic production of liquid transportation fuels and hydrogen, 2) provide education and training in the field of bioenergy for underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students, 3) support the career development of underrepresented postdoctoral research associates and young faculty members in the field of bioenergy, 4) serve as a pipeline for K-12, community college, undergraduate, and graduate students into bioenergy related STEM disciplines and careers, and 5) create an interdisciplinary community of learning, discovery, and engagement at NCA&T that promotes excellence and internal and external collaboration in the bioenergy area.

Intellectual Merit: the efficient and economic production of energy from biomass and other renewable natural resources is necessary to transform the U.S. energy industry to energy independence and sustainability. Thermochemical catalytic conversion of biomass to liquid fuels and hydrogen is recognized as a technology critical to achieving this transformation.  Some promising demonstration projects have recently been undertaken, but much fundamental and applied research remains to be done to improve process efficiencies and economics to meet renewable fuel standards and transform the U.S. energy industry.

To provide a national resource for improving the efficiencies and economics of thermochemical biomass conversion technology, the Bioenergy Center's research is focused in three thrust areas: (I) Production of high-quality synthesis gas (mixture containing varying amounts of CO and H2) by biomass gasification, (II) Conversion of synthesis gas to liquid fuels and hydrogen, and (III) Reforming and processing of biofuels for fuel cells. Innovative outcomes of the research include: (1) deeper understanding of biomass gasification chemistry, (2) computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and process modeling of fluidized bed gasification of biomass, (3) microreactors for efficient catalyst screening, (4) novel multi-metallic catalysts that produce H2 with minimal CO formation to avoid deactivation of the catalyst, (5) membrane-reactor systems that produce high-purity H2 from reforming reactions, (6) Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) electrodes that have CO-tolerant, high-surface area, low Pt-loading electrocatalyst, and (7) economic analysis of technology choices that is explicitly conditioned on biomass and energy prices as well as bioenergy policy provisions.

Broader Impacts: The Bioenergy Center has involved 10 diverse faculty from 6 departments at NCA&T and 1 faculty member at Louisiana Tech. The center provided research and curriculum development experiences for 4 K-12 teachers and Energy Day experiences for hundreds of K-12 students. Training and financial support has been provided for 17 Ph.D. (13 graduated), 25 M.S. (20 graduated), and 22 B.S. students (17 graduated) along with postdoctoral researchers (3 full-time and 2 temporary). Labs have been established and improved: the Biomass Gasification Lab has been upgraded with a chemical looping process and in-line gas chromatograph detection and analysis equipment for chemical analysis of syngas products; the Computational Process Engineering Lab was upgraded to include reduce order computational modeling of biomass gasification and the latest version of ANSYS Fluent software for computational fluid dynamic modeling of fluidized-bed gasification; the Fuel Cell Lab was upgraded with a fuel cell test station; and a new Microreactor Lab was developed that provides fast and material efficient screening and optimization of catalysts. The research has generated 54 journal articles (plus 7 under review), 10 Ph.D. dissertations, and 126 conference presentations. An invention disclosure was submitted to the NC A&T Technology Transfer Office (A Novel Sensitization and Activation Method to Nucleate Pd-seed Deep in Macropores), and a provisional patent application was filed by Louisiana Tech (Initial Predictor of Fischer Tropsch Catalytic Activity). Through a CREST supplement a partnership has been established with Stony Brook University. Partnerships have been developed with local industries including Southern Research Institute and RTI International that include graduate student internships. Several international presentations including a keynote talk on Bioenergy were presented. Partnerships and student-exchanges with two international universities are being negotiated. The CREST Center for Bioenergy co-sponsored an international Symposium on Thermal and Catalytic Sciences for Biofuels and Biobased Products, November 1-4, 2016, Chapel Hill, NC. This popular meeting provided early career scientists and engineers an opportunity to present their research and interact with senior researchers in the thermochemical bioenergy community. An A&T graduate student was one of three students to receive an outstanding poster award.


Last Modified: 05/31/2018
Modified by: Abolghasem Shahbazi

    Catalyst

Its objectives are to: 1) conduct fundamental research towards the development of advanced thermochemical biomass conversion technology and intellectual property for the efficient and economic production of liquid transportation fuels and hydrogen, 2) provide education and training in the field of bioenergy for underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students, 3) support the career development of underrepresented postdoctoral research associates and young faculty members in the field of bioenergy, 4) serve as a pipeline for K-12, community college, undergraduate, and graduate students into bioenergy related STEM disciplines and careers, and 5) create an interdisciplinary community of learning, discovery, and engagement at NCA&T that promotes excellence and internal and external collaboration in the bioenergy area. To provide a national resource for improving the efficiencies and economics of thermochemical biomass conversion technology, the Bioenergy Center's research is focused in three thrust areas: (I) Production of high-quality synthesis gas (mixture containing varying amounts of CO and H2) by biomass gasification, (II) Conversion of synthesis gas to liquid fuels and hydrogen, and (III) Reforming and processing of biofuels for fuel cells. Through a CREST supplement a partnership has been established with Stony Brook University. Partnerships have been developed with local industries including Southern Research Institute and RTI International that include graduate student internships. The CREST Center for Bioenergy co-sponsored an international Symposium on Thermal and Catalytic Sciences for Biofuels and Biobased Products, November 1-4, 2016, Chapel Hill, NC. This popular meeting provided early career scientists and engineers an opportunity to present their research and interact with senior researchers in the thermochemical bioenergy community.
